description:
Brachybacterium massiliense is a species of bacteria that belongs to the Brachybacterium genus. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, non-spore-forming, and non-motile bacterium. Cells of B. massiliense are coccoid or short-rod shaped and typically measure around 0.5-1.0 μm in diameter.

This species was first isolated from a human clinical sample in Marseille, France, and was described in 2012. Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences indicates that B. massiliense is closely related to other Brachybacterium species, such as B. faecium and B. paraconglomeratum.

Brachybacterium massiliense is chemoheterotrophic, meaning it requires organic compounds as both carbon and energy sources for growth. It is able to hydrolyze esculin and casein, and can utilize a variety of carbohydrates, including glucose, fructose, and sucrose, for growth.

The optimal growth temperature for B. massiliense is around 37°C, and it can grow in the presence of up to 10% NaCl. Further research is needed to fully understand the ecology, physiology, and potential clinical or environmental significance of this bacterial species.
